content.description: Start on the obvious jug at the horizontal break and follow the path of least resistance on the left side of the boulder, brushing past a small tree on climber's left.
content.location: This is the first boulder on your left as you approach from the Main Entrance

content.description: Start on the obvious large jug the horizontal break and climb up increasingly smaller holds on the face and toss for the lip (crux).
content.location: This is the first boulder on your left, as you approach from the Main Entrance.

content.description: Sit start on an obvious flake jug and make two moves upward on crimps and then traverse left to a mantel topout.
content.location: From the Trudeau main area, walk 20 feet down the trail till you reach the next large boulders, walk around to the opposite side of these boulders.

content.description: Sit start on the obvious flake jug. Climb up on crimps and top out directly above the start. Exceptionally stupid.
content.location: From the Trudeau main area, walk 20 feet down the trail till you reach the next large boulders, walk around to the opposite side of these boulders. Stupid Overhang is the obvious overhanging boulder with a large flake jug at the bottom.

content.description: A fun variation that tops out on the left side of Kelly’s. Same start as Kelly’s Problem but instead of busting out right to the good large crystal crimp on Kelly’s, throw a heal up on the sloping ledge and mantel up.
content.location: Start as for Kelly’s Problem, horizontal jug under the block.

content.description: Just to the right of the Trudeau Face, is a large refrigerator-shaped block protruding from the hillside with a crack that forms its right-side (Corona Crack) with an adjacent boulder. Start at the base in a small cave-like feature on a jug at a horizontal break with feet on a large ledge. Climb straight up the block, busting right to a good crimp on the face with a large crystal, and straight up to the apex of the boulder. I did not use any holds or features on the boulder to the right. I don’t think you need them, the way it climbs, but forcing the route to use the adjacent boulder would certainly change to climb but not the difficulty.
content.location: This is the first and main boulder on the trail as you approach from the Main Entrance (from Tom 's Cabin, travelling counterclockwise around the southern loop), located just to the right of the Trudeau Face

content.description: Start on side pull angling crimps and continue up and left to the apex of the boulder. Using the arete makes it easier.
content.location: From the Trudeau main area, walk 20 feet down the trail till you reach the next large boulders, walk around to the opposite side of these boulders.

content.description: Start on an obvious large jug and follow more large jugs to an easy top out.
content.location: From the Trudeau main area, walk 20 feet down the trail till you reach the next large boulders, walk around to the opposite side of these boulders. The Angler boulder is immediately right of the obvious stupid overhang boulder.

content.description: This route climbs the obvious crack starting in a small cave, immediately right of Kelly's Problem. Start in the cave with the left side of your body facing in, with hand jams to start and your back towards the slab, which forms the starting holds for Kelly's Problem. Jam your way out of the bombay-like feature, trying not to dab, and onto the face through the notch between the boulders. A suprisingly good crack problem.
content.location: Located just right of Kelly's Problem, on the left side of the trail as you approach from the main entrance.

content.description: This boulder field is the most concentrated and features some decent problems.
